description.EN:
"The dataset contains data on Import and Export Value (expressed in 1000US$) for a selected list of fertilizers, see below, from 1961onwards. 
Country and country aggregate data are available. The fertilizers covered are: Nitrogenous fertilizers; Phosphate fertilizers; Potash fertilizers; Fertilizers Manufactured, nes; Fertilizers, Organic; Natural Phosphates; Natural Potassic Salts; Natural Sodium Nitrate
"

statisticalConceptsDefinitions.EN: The variables provided are  Import and Export of selected fertilizer items expressed in terms of 1000US$.

statisticalPopulation.EN: All countries.

statisticalUnit.EN: Whole agricultural sector.

coverageSectorsDetails.EN: The agricultural sector is covered.

releaseCalendar.EN:
The data are disseminated once a year .
Dates for new data releases are pre-announced on the FAOSTAT3 website.  
Unrestricted and free access to all users to the same datasets. Confidential data are neither collected nor disseminated. Users are informed through the FAOSTAT release calendar.

clarity.EN:
"Fertilizer methodology available at:
http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/ess/ess_test_folder/Publications/Agrienvironmental/Methodologocal_Notes_FAOSTAT2011.pdf
http://faostat.fao.org/site/575/default.aspx#ancor (About the fertilizer module)
Manual on Fertilizer Statistics - FAO Economic and Social Development Paper N° 102 "

confidentialityPolicy.EN: FAO Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, Principle 10: "All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning people and legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and are used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation."

confidentialityDataTreatment.EN: Only non-confidential data are collected and recorded.

qualityAssessment.EN: The quality of data varies considerably between countries.  There are no routines for accessing the quality, except for some input validation. . More information on metadata and certain validation procedures at country level is certainly needed;

qualityAssurance.EN: The data come from National tapes elaborated in cooperation with the ESS TRADE group through the application of a specific routine and, if necessary, they are cross-checked with the UN COMTRADE data. See also the FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework is available http://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf

accuracyNonSampling.EN:
It is not possible to asses the accuracy but as there is a substantial amount of estimated or imputed data points, the accuracy for certain products, countries and regions is not that good.

No information available of the magnitude on non-sampling errors.  One such category of errors is measurement errors which are due mainly to lack of harmonisation in statistical methods. For instance, when FAO concepts do not fit with national concepts, there may be significant measurement errors.

revisionPolicy.EN:
"In case a country send revised data  the revision is reflected in the database.
"

revisionPractice.EN: The revised data are disseminated at the same time of the updated series (once a year).

userNeeds.EN: The main users are FAO analysts, other international organizations, ministries and government agencies, agro-industry, trade and professional associations, research institutes and universities, journalists and general public.  FAO is not aware of unmet needs.

userSatisfaction.EN: No user satisfaction studies have been conducted which may explain why FAO is not aware of unmet user needs.

completeness.EN: The dataset is fairly complete.

comparabilityGeographical.EN: There is limited geographical comparability due to differences between countries in methods and coverage, except for regions with homogenous countries, e.g. EU countries, which are bound by EU regulations on methods, and OECD countries.

comparabilityTime.EN: Some breaks occur when a new version of the HS classification is adopted to record international trade

coherenceIntern.EN:
A data reconciliation meeting is held annually with the International Fertilizer Association. Production and trade domains seem to be rather coherent, at least for some countries.

It is expected that the internal coherence is checked by countries before sending data to FAO. FAO is not aware of any incoherence for the present dataset vis-à-vis other corresponding datasets

timeliness.EN: Questionnaires are generally sent to countries in August and two follow -up are made to non responding countries. generally a first release of preliminary/partial data is available in March for the Fertilizer meeting. After that all the compilation process go ahead and the set of data for uploading is generally ready in July.

maintenanceAgency.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

rawDataDescription.EN: National data are received from countries.

dataCollection.EN:
"The data come from National tapes elaborated in cooperation with the ESS TRADE group through the application of a specific routine and, if necessary, they are cross-checked with the UN COMTRADE data.
In case national tapes are not available,  national publications and the UN COMTRADE database (Reporter and mirror trade) are used as sources."

"The trade data originates from reported National trade data which are elaborated in cooperation with the ESS TRADE group through the application of a specific routine and, if necessary, they are cross-checked with the UN COMTRADE data.
In case national trade data are not available,  national publications and the UN COMTRADE database (Reporter and mirror trade) are used as sources.
In case data are received in local currencies a conversion factor (IMF one) for converting in US$ is used."

organization.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

contactInfo.address: Economic and Social Development Department Viale delle Terme di Caracalla  00153 Rome, Italy

description.EN: The detailed food and agriculture trade data collected, processed and disseminated by FAO according to the standard International Merchandise Trade Statistics Methodology, is mainly provided by the national authorities and other international organizations.  The trade database includes the  following variables: export quantity, export value and export unit value, import quantity, import value and import unit value. The  trade database includes all food and agriculture products imported/exported annually by all the countries in the world.

statisticalConceptsDefinitions.EN:
Quantity of food and agricultural exports: Export quantity is defined by the IMTS as the physical quantity of domestic origin or manufacture products shipped out of the country. It includes re-exports. According to FAO methodology the quantity of food and agricultural exports included in the FAOSTAT database is expressed in terms of weight (tonnes) for all commodities except for live animals which are expressed in units (heads); poultry, rabbits, pigeons and other birds are expressed in thousand units. As a general rule, trade quantity refers to net weight, excluding any sort of container. Value of agricultural exports: Value of agricultural exports should be reported in national currency, US dollars or other currency. Export values are mostly reported as FOB. In the FAOSTAT database export values are expressed in thousand US dollars.  Quantity of food and agricultural imports: Import quantity represents the physical quantity of the products imported for domestic consumption or processing shipped into a country. It includes imports for re-export. According to FAO methodology the quantity of food and agricultural imports included in the FAOSTAT database is expressed in terms of weight (tones) for all commodities except for live animals which are expressed in units (heads); poultry, rabbits, pigeons and other birds are expressed in thousand units. As a general rule, trade quantity refers to net weight, excluding any sort of container. It includes also food aid quantity. Value of agricultural imports: Value of agricultural imports should be reported in national currency, US dollars or other currency. Import values are mostly reported as CIF (cost insurance and freight). In the FAOSTAT database import values are expressed in thousand US dollars
ELEMENTS:
Export Quantity [1000 heads]
Export Quantity [No]
Export Quantity [heads]
Export Value [1000 USD]
Import Quantity [1000 heads]
Import Quantity [No]
Import Quantity [heads]
Import Value [1000 USD]

Inclusions: The following transactions are generally included in international trade in goods statistics: Barter trade, goods on consignment, goods on financial lease, goods traded between enterprises under common ownership, goods traded on government account and goods with a view or following processing. Exclusions: The following transactions are excluded from international trade in goods statistics for conceptual or methodological reasons:  Goods in simple transit, Temporary trade, Particular trade not subject of a commercial transaction, Supply for national arm forces stationed abroad, embassies and emergency aid for disaster areas, Means of payment and monetary gold and Goods for and after repair.

statisticalPopulation.EN: All trade data on food and agriculture products including livestock complied by all customs offices in the country. (for intra-EU trade, the statistical population is all trade operators recording trade transactions over a certain threshold). Total Merchandise import/export value is also included

statisticalUnit.EN: All crops and livestock products registered by the custom office in the country. In case of non custom trade data the observation unit is the trade operator.(Within intra-EU trade statistics: any taxable person carrying out intra-EU trade is responsible for providing information). See IMTS compiler manual, edition 2012.

coverageSectorsDetails.EN: All food and agriculture products imported and exported during the reference year by country. In addition to the individual country data, other  item and country aggregates are disseminated. The processed trade data is essential for the compilation of Supply/Utilization Accounts (SUA) and Food Balance Sheets (FBS).

title.EN: FAOSTAT website, FAO Global Statistical Yearbook, FAO Regional Statistical Yearbooks.

organization.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) Statistics Division (ESS)

contactInfo.address: Economic and Social Development Department Viale delle Terme di Caracalla  00153 Rome, Italy

legalActsAgreements.EN:
Article I of the constitution indeed requires the Organization to collect, analyze, interpret and disseminate information relating to nutrition, food and agriculture (the term “agriculture” and its derivatives includes forestry, fisheries and aquaculture). The first session of the FAO Conference in 1945 provided the rationale: “If FAO is to carry out its work successfully it will need to know where and why hunger and malnutrition exist, what forms they take, and how widespread they are. Such data will serve as a basis for making plans, determining the efficacy of measures used, and measuring progress from time to time.” Member countries reaffirmed this mandate in 2000 when formulating the Organization’s strategic thrusts for the 2000-2015 period: Corporate Strategy E1 commits the Organization to building “an integrated information resource base, with current, relevant and reliable statistics, information and knowledge made accessible to all FAO clients. FAO, through ESS, is member of the Task Force of International Merchandise Trade Statistics (TF-IMTS) coordinated by UNSD and contributes together with other international organizations to improve the IMTS methodology as well as to implement it at the country level. FAO through ESS is also member of the Expert Group of Global Trade Statistics together with other international organizations and selected countries.
"FAO trade statistics follows the international standards provided by the IMTS which is periodically revised by UNSD with the contribution of other international organizations and the member countries. The original version was issued in 1970 (United Nations publication, Sales No. E.70.XVII.16) and the first revised
version in 1982 (United Nations publication, Sales No. E.82.XVII.14) . At its forty-first session, the Statistical Commission adopted International
Merchandise Trade Statistics: Concepts And Definitions, 2010 (IMTS 2010)1 and
endorsed the proposed implementation programme, including the preparation of the revision of International Merchandise Trade Statistics: Compilers Manual2 and supporting technical assistance activities (see E/2010/24, chap. I.B, decision 41/103, para. (b)). In the same decision (para. (c)), the Commission requested the Expert Group on International Merchandise Trade Statistics and the Task Force on International Merchandise Trade Statistics to continue their work, focus on the implementation of IMTS 2010 and give due consideration to national circumstances, the harmonization of national and regional compilation practices and the conduct of related comparison studies. The  legal acts concerning the trade statistics at national levels are available on the country websites."

institutionalMandateDataSharing.EN: Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with UNSD on the implementation of IMTS and the data exchange, Mutual agreement with Eurostat on data sharing, cooperation WTO on accessing the CDS database in order to update the Total merchandise statistics.

releaseCalendar.EN:
Dates for new data releases are pre-announced on the FAOSTAT3 website.
In line with FAO’s Statistics Code of Practice data are disseminated on FAO's website  respecting professional independence and in an objective, professional and transparent manner in which all users are treated equitably.

clarity.EN:
The FAO trade statistics is implemented according to the IMTS methodology and standards adopted by the UN Statistics Commission and implemented by UNSD. The main methodologies on trade statistics are available at: http://unstats.un.org/unsd/trade/imts/imts_default.htm 
No quality reports or studies made by FAO.  No national quality reports collected. However, data are carefully reviewed and checked by FAO at least twice per year.

confidentialityPolicy.EN:
According to the confidentiality recommendations formulated by IMTS compiler manual. Country confidentiality rules are available in the national publications or websites.
FAO Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, Principle 10: "All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning people and legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and are used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation."

confidentialityDataTreatment.EN: IMTS recommendations on trade data confidentiality are applied by FAO on trade statistics. In particular only the aggregated data (by FCL classification) are disseminated on the external website. The detailed trade data reported by countries by 8-12 digits HS code and by partners are not disseminated on the external FAOSTAT website. The detailed trade data is only disseminated in the internal FAOSTAT website in order to be shared with all internal FAO users (to eliminate the duplication of the data collection) under TF_source database:http://faostat.local.fao.org/site/588/default.aspx

qualityAssessment.EN: The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

qualityAssurance.EN:
"The FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework is available http://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf
The FAO trade data processing system incorporate various data quality modules manly to identify the data inconsistencies as the trade unit value outliers, discrepancies between the reporting data and the trading partner declarations, global trade unbalance by item or group of items etc ."

accuracyNonSampling.EN:
The main source of errors is the deviation from the standard IMTS methodology and recommendations in reporting annual trade data by various countries.  Incomplete country metadata is another source of errors especially on the description of the unit of measurement used at the very detailed level of reporting data. Trade data accuracy is affected by specific characteristics such as the practice of concealing confidential information and the exemption thresholds applied by countries in order to reduce the burden on enterprises. The lack of country tariff line description generate various ambiguities on the link between HS and FCL. Another sources of errors is generated by the current FAO trade data processing system which is over 10 years old.  It is expected to be replaced in order to create new facilities on trade data validation. The FAOSTAT working system, which is also obsolete, is soon to be replaced.
The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

accuracySampling.EN: The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

revisionPolicy.EN: Preliminary trade data reported by certain countries are substituted by the final trade data if reported. In some cases the missing trade data are also updated according to the new data sources received

revisionPractice.EN: Usually, the revised data for n-1 to n-5 is included in the global validation of the trade data; cross checking with other trade data bases is also used to updated the trade statistics in the last 5 years.

userNeeds.EN:
The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

The main user of the annual trade statistics is the internal system used for the compilation of the SUA/FBS. The trade data received by FAO are also shared with Fishery department and other FAO units. Many other FAO analysts are consulting the FAOSTAT trade database or the internal trade databases, other international organizations. Another users are:  NGOs , trade and professional associations, research institutes and universities, journalists and general public. So far no unmet user needs have been recorded.

userSatisfaction.EN: No user satisfaction studies have been conducted  on trade module of FAOSTAT.  However, feed-back from users are recorded. A user satisfaction survey was conducted some years ago on global FAOSTAT dissemination website.

completeness.EN: As mentioned above (see 12.2) about 5% of total trade is missing and the information is imputed using the mirror statistics.

comparabilityGeographical.EN: The mirror data cross checking is one of the methods used to validate trade data. The inconsistency between the declaration of the reporter and partner countries could be generated by the trade methodology applied /general trade system versus special trade system, the latter in the case of extra-EU trade statistics)) by the classification used as well as by the country coverage. Geographical comparability depends on which countries and groups of countries that are compared.  For some countries the comparability is fairly good whilst for others it is less good. It should be noted, however, that accuracy and comparability is very much dependent on customs practices, definitions and policies in individual countries. It shold also be noted that of all the customs activities only a few dimensions are collected purely for statistical purpose.

comparabilityTime.EN: Break in time series could be generated by the changes on the country classifications( see issue such as Sudan and South Sudan and the enlargement of the EU) as well as due to the revision of the HS classification (version 2007 is currently used but for 2012 reference year the HS2012 will be implemented) .  For periods when data are compiled according to one and the same HS classification comparability over time is rather good.

coherenceIntern.EN:
FAO trade data have rather good coherence with FAO production data and producer price data, at least for certain countries, as they are based on the same classifications. Apart from the International Trade Statistics, information on trade flows can be found in National Accounts, Business Statistics and Balance of Payments. The compilation of the data and the production of the above mentioned statistics follow the recommendations (sources and methods) of different international organisations, i.e. Eurostat, International Monetary Fund (IMF), United Nations (UN), etc. The Quality Report on International Trade Statistics documents the main differences between these sources in terms of concepts and definitions, statistical unit or object, classification used, geographical breakdown, reference period and correction methods.
The internal coherence of data are generally good.

timeliness.EN: Data are uploaded for dissemination twice a year, irrespectively when they arrive at FAO.

punctuality.EN: Annually about 140 countries report regularly trade statistics.

label.EN: Other sources and mixture of data source

rawDataDescription.EN: Until 2012, FAO sent a trade data requests to all the countries and then in June the FAO-UNSD joint letter was sent. As from 2012, ESS has stopped sending the trade data requests, except for the joint FAO-UNSD follow up request which was sent by UNSD in July 2012.

dataCollection.EN:
"The main source is official statistics from FAO member countries.  Other sources are: 1. WFP food aid data base – to capture the food aid data which is not included into the commercial trade and is missing from UNSD and GTIS database
2. WTO-CDS – this is Common data set, consolidated data base on total merchandise trade, maintained by WTO with the contribution of UNSD, OECD, ITC etc
3. IMF annual exchange rate – used to convert national currency into US $ 
4. National web databases, national and international publications to update the  trade data for the non reporting countries which are missing from COMTRADE and GTIS
Exceptionally, unofficial data are also used as well as imputed data.  the data is ""flagged"". 
The statistical value: International trade in goods statistics apply harmonised principles when compiling the statistical value of trade flows. In general all goods should be valued with the total amount which would be invoiced in case of sale or purchase at the national border of the reporting country. The statistical value does not include taxes on export or import, such as customs duties, value added tax, excise duty, levies, export refunds or other taxes with similar effect. It includes only incidental expenses (freight, insurance) incurred, in the case of exports/dispatches, in the part of the journey located on the territory of the reporting Member State and, in the case of imports/arrivals, in the part of the journey located outside the territory of the reporting country. It is said to be a FOB value (free on board), for exports/dispatches, and a CIF value (cost, insurance, freight) for imports/arrivals.

organization.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

contactInfo.address: Economic and Social Development Department Viale delle Terme di Caracalla  00153 Rome, Italy

description.EN: The detailed food and agriculture trade data collected, processed and disseminated by FAO according to the standard International Merchandise Trade Statistics Methodology, is mainly provided by the national authorities and other international organizations.  The trade database includes the  following variables: export quantity, export value and export unit value, import quantity, import value and import unit value. The  trade database includes all food and agriculture products imported/exported annually by all the countries in the world.

statisticalConceptsDefinitions.EN:
Unit value of agricultural imports/exports: Unit value of the imported/ exported commodity is the amount actually paid for one unit (by quantity unit) of the given commodity when sold for importation/exportation from/to the compiling country; the unit value is calculated as the report between the trade value and the trade quantity. In FAOSTAT database the unit value is expressed in US dollars per tonne, US dollars per live animal or US dollars per 1 000 heads in the case of poultry, rabbits, pigeons and other birds. Agricultural import/export quantity/value index: Quantity/value indices represent the changes in the price-weighted sum of quantities of food and agriculture products traded between countries. The weights are the unit value averages of 2004-2006. The formulas used are of the Laspeyres type. Indices for food products include commodities that are considered edible and contain nutrients, except for animal feed products and alcoholic beverages. Coffee and tea are also excluded because, although edible, they have practically no nutritive value. For countries which report import values on f.o.b. (free on board) basis, these are adjusted to approximate c.i.f. values (by a standard factor of 112 percent). Agricultural import/export unit value index: Unit value indices represent the changes in the quantity-weighted unit values of products traded between countries. The weights are the quantity averages of 2004-2006. The formulas used are of the Laspeyres type. Import/Export Value, Base Period Quantity and Import/Export Base Period Price are derived from the variables above.  The variables listed above are measured for the following two aggregates: Total Agriculture Products and Food excluding Fish.  
ELEMENTS:
Export Quantity Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]
Export Unit/Value Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]
Export Value Base Price [1000 USD]
Export Value Base Quantity [1000 USD]
Export Value Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]
Import Quantity Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]
Import Unit/Value Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]
Import Value Base Period Price [1000 USD]
Import Value Base Period Quantity [1000 USD]
Import Value Index (2004-2006 = 100) [%]


Inclusions: The following transactions are generally included in international trade in goods statistics: Barter trade, goods on consignment, goods on financial lease, goods traded between enterprises under common ownership, goods traded on government account and goods with a view or following processing. Exclusions: The following transactions are excluded from international trade in goods statistics for conceptual or methodological reasons:  Goods in simple transit, Temporary trade, Particular trade not subject of a commercial transaction, Supply for national arm forces stationed abroad, embassies and emergency aid for disaster areas, Means of payment and monetary gold and Goods for and after repair.

statisticalPopulation.EN: All trade data on food and agriculture products including livestock complied by all customs offices in the country. (for intra-EU trade, the statistical population is all trade operators recording trade transactions over a certain threshold). Total Merchandise import/export value is also included

statisticalUnit.EN: All crops and livestock products registered by the custom office in the country. In case of non custom trade data the observation unit is the trade operator.(Within intra-EU trade statistics: any taxable person carrying out intra-EU trade is responsible for providing information). See IMTS compiler manual, edition 2012.

coverageSectorsDetails.EN: All food and agriculture products imported and exported during the reference year by country. In addition to the individual country data, other  item and country aggregates are disseminated. The processed trade data is essential for the compilation of Supply/Utilization Accounts (SUA) and Food Balance Sheets (FBS).

title.EN: FAOSTAT website, FAO Global Statistical Yearbook, FAO Regional Statistical Yearbooks.

organization.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

contactInfo.address: Economic and Social Development Department Viale delle Terme di Caracalla  00153 Rome, Italy

legalActsAgreements.EN:
Article I of the constitution indeed requires the Organization to collect, analyze, interpret and disseminate information relating to nutrition, food and agriculture (the term “agriculture” and its derivatives includes forestry, fisheries and aquaculture). The first session of the FAO Conference in 1945 provided the rationale: “If FAO is to carry out its work successfully it will need to know where and why hunger and malnutrition exist, what forms they take, and how widespread they are. Such data will serve as a basis for making plans, determining the efficacy of measures used, and measuring progress from time to time.” Member countries reaffirmed this mandate in 2000 when formulating the Organization’s strategic thrusts for the 2000-2015 period: Corporate Strategy E1 commits the Organization to building “an integrated information resource base, with current, relevant and reliable statistics, information and knowledge made accessible to all FAO clients. FAO, through ESS, is member of the Task Force of International Merchandise Trade Statistics (TF-IMTS) coordinated by UNSD and contributes together with other international organizations to improve the IMTS methodology as well as to implement it at the country level. FAO through ESS is also member of the Expert Group of Global Trade Statistics together with other international organizations and selected countries.
"FAO trade statistics follows the international standards provided by the IMTS which is periodically revised by UNSD with the contribution of other international organizations and the member countries. The original version was issued in 1970 (United Nations publication, Sales No. E.70.XVII.16) and the first revised
version in 1982 (United Nations publication, Sales No. E.82.XVII.14) . At its forty-first session, the Statistical Commission adopted International
Merchandise Trade Statistics: Concepts And Definitions, 2010 (IMTS 2010)1 and
endorsed the proposed implementation programme, including the preparation of the revision of International Merchandise Trade Statistics: Compilers Manual2 and supporting technical assistance activities (see E/2010/24, chap. I.B, decision 41/103, para. (b)). In the same decision (para. (c)), the Commission requested the Expert Group on International Merchandise Trade Statistics and the Task Force on International Merchandise Trade Statistics to continue their work, focus on the implementation of IMTS 2010 and give due consideration to national circumstances, the harmonization of national and regional compilation practices and the conduct of related comparison studies. The  legal acts concerning the trade statistics at national levels are available on the country websites."

institutionalMandateDataSharing.EN: Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with UNSD on the implementation of IMTS and the data exchange, Mutual agreement with Eurostat on data sharing, cooperation WTO on accessing the CDS database in order to update the Total merchandise statistics.

releaseCalendar.EN:
Dates for new data releases are pre-announced on the FAOSTAT3 website.
In line with FAO’s Statistics Code of Practice data are disseminated on FAO's website  respecting professional independence and in an objective, professional and transparent manner in which all users are treated equitably.

clarity.EN:
The FAO trade statistics is implemented according to the IMTS methodology and standards adopted by the UN Statistics Commission and implemented by UNSD. The main methodologies on trade statistics are available at: http://unstats.un.org/unsd/trade/imts/imts_default.htm 
No quality reports or studies made by FAO.  No national quality reports collected. However, data are carefully reviewed and checked by FAO at least twice per year.

confidentialityPolicy.EN:
According to the confidentiality recommendations formulated by IMTS compiler manual. Country confidentiality rules are available in the national publications or websites.
FAO Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, Principle 10: "All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning people and legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and are used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation."

confidentialityDataTreatment.EN: IMTS recommendations on trade data confidentiality are applied by FAO on trade statistics. In particular only the aggregated data (by FCL classification) are disseminated on the external website. The detailed trade data reported by countries by 8-12 digits HS code and by partners are not disseminated on the external FAOSTAT website. The detailed trade data is only disseminated in the internal FAOSTAT website in order to be shared with all internal FAO users (to eliminate the duplication of the data collection) under TF_source database:http://faostat.local.fao.org/site/588/default.aspx

qualityAssessment.EN: The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

qualityAssurance.EN:
"The FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework is available http://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf
The FAO trade data processing system incorporate various data quality modules manly to identify the data inconsistencies as the trade unit value outliers, discrepancies between the reporting data and the trading partner declarations, global trade unbalance by item or group of items etc ."

accuracyNonSampling.EN:
The main source of errors is the deviation from the standard IMTS methodology and recommendations in reporting annual trade data by various countries.  Incomplete country metadata is another source of errors especially on the description of the unit of measurement used at the very detailed level of reporting data. Trade data accuracy is affected by specific characteristics such as the practice of concealing confidential information and the exemption thresholds applied by countries in order to reduce the burden on enterprises. The lack of country tariff line description generate various ambiguities on the link between HS and FCL. Another sources of errors is generated by the current FAO trade data processing system which is over 10 years old.  It is expected to be replaced in order to create new facilities on trade data validation. The FAOSTAT working system, which is also obsolete, is soon to be replaced.
The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

accuracySampling.EN: The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

revisionPolicy.EN: Preliminary trade data reported by certain countries are substituted by the final trade data if reported. In some cases the missing trade data are also updated according to the new data sources received

revisionPractice.EN: Usually, the revised data for n-1 to n-5 is included in the global validation of the trade data; cross checking with other trade data bases is also used to updated the trade statistics in the last 5 years.

userNeeds.EN:
The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

The main user of the annual trade statistics is the internal system used for the compilation of the SUA/FBS. The trade data received by FAO are also shared with Fishery department and other FAO units. Many other FAO analysts are consulting the FAOSTAT trade database or the internal trade databases, other international organizations. Another users are:  NGOs , trade and professional associations, research institutes and universities, journalists and general public. So far no unmet user needs have been recorded.

userSatisfaction.EN: No user satisfaction studies have been conducted  on trade module of FAOSTAT.  However, feed-back from users are recorded. A user satisfaction survey was conducted some years ago on global FAOSTAT dissemination website.

completeness.EN: As mentioned above (see 12.2) about 5% of total trade is missing and the information is imputed using the mirror statistics.

comparabilityGeographical.EN: The mirror data cross checking is one of the methods used to validate trade data. The inconsistency between the declaration of the reporter and partner countries could be generated by the trade methodology applied /general trade system versus special trade system, the latter in the case of extra-EU trade statistics)) by the classification used as well as by the country coverage. Geographical comparability depends on which countries and groups of countries that are compared.  For some countries the comparability is fairly good whilst for others it is less good. It should be noted, however, that accuracy and comparability is very much dependent on customs practices, definitions and policies in individual countries. It shold also be noted that of all the customs activities only a few dimensions are collected purely for statistical purpose.

comparabilityTime.EN: Break in time series could be generated by the changes on the country classifications( see issue such as Sudan and South Sudan and the enlargement of the EU) as well as due to the revision of the HS classification (version 2007 is currently used but for 2012 reference year the HS2012 will be implemented) .  For periods when data are compiled according to one and the same HS classification comparability over time is rather good.

coherenceIntern.EN:
FAO trade data have rather good coherence with FAO production data and producer price data, at least for certain countries, as they are based on the same classifications. Apart from the International Trade Statistics, information on trade flows can be found in National Accounts, Business Statistics and Balance of Payments. The compilation of the data and the production of the above mentioned statistics follow the recommendations (sources and methods) of different international organisations, i.e. Eurostat, International Monetary Fund (IMF), United Nations (UN), etc. The Quality Report on International Trade Statistics documents the main differences between these sources in terms of concepts and definitions, statistical unit or object, classification used, geographical breakdown, reference period and correction methods.
The internal coherence of data are generally good.

timeliness.EN: Data are uploaded for dissemination twice a year, irrespectively when they arrive at FAO.

punctuality.EN: Annually about 140 countries report regularly trade statistics.

label.EN: Other sources and mixture of data source

rawDataDescription.EN: Until 2012, FAO sent a trade data requests to all the countries and then in June the FAO-UNSD joint letter was sent. As from 2012, ESS has stopped sending the trade data requests, except for the joint FAO-UNSD follow up request which was sent by UNSD in July 2012.

dataCollection.EN:
"The main source is official statistics from FAO member countries.  Other sources are: 1. WFP food aid data base – to capture the food aid data which is not included into the commercial trade and is missing from UNSD and GTIS database
2. WTO-CDS – this is Common data set, consolidated data base on total merchandise trade, maintained by WTO with the contribution of UNSD, OECD, ITC etc
3. IMF annual exchange rate – used to convert national currency into US $ 
4. National web databases, national and international publications to update the  trade data for the non reporting countries which are missing from COMTRADE and GTIS
Exceptionally, unofficial data are also used as well as imputed data.  the data is ""flagged"". 
The statistical value: International trade in goods statistics apply harmonised principles when compiling the statistical value of trade flows. In general all goods should be valued with the total amount which would be invoiced in case of sale or purchase at the national border of the reporting country. The statistical value does not include taxes on export or import, such as customs duties, value added tax, excise duty, levies, export refunds or other taxes with similar effect. It includes only incidental expenses (freight, insurance) incurred, in the case of exports/dispatches, in the part of the journey located on the territory of the reporting Member State and, in the case of imports/arrivals, in the part of the journey located outside the territory of the reporting country. It is said to be a FOB value (free on board), for exports/dispatches, and a CIF value (cost, insurance, freight) for imports/arrivals.

organization.EN: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

contactInfo.address: Economic and Social Development Department Viale delle Terme di Caracalla  00153 Rome, Italy

description.EN: The detailed food and agriculture trade data collected, processed and disseminated by FAO according to the standard International Merchandise Trade Statistics Methodology, is mainly provided by the national authorities and other international organizations.  The trade database includes the  following variables: export quantity, export value and export unit value, import quantity, import value and import unit value. The  trade database includes all food and agriculture products imported/exported annually by all the countries in the world.

statisticalConceptsDefinitions.EN:
Quantity of food and agricultural exports: Export quantity is defined by the IMTS as the physical quantity of domestic origin or manufacture products shipped out of the country. It includes re-exports. According to FAO methodology the quantity of food and agricultural exports included in the FAOSTAT database is expressed in terms of weight (tonnes) for all commodities except for live animals which are expressed in units (heads); poultry, rabbits, pigeons and other birds are expressed in thousand units. As a general rule, trade quantity refers to net weight, excluding any sort of container. Value of agricultural exports: Value of agricultural exports should be reported in national currency, US dollars or other currency. Export values are mostly reported as FOB. In the FAOSTAT database export values are expressed in thousand US dollars.  Quantity of food and agricultural imports: Import quantity represents the physical quantity of the products imported for domestic consumption or processing shipped into a country. It includes imports for re-export. According to FAO methodology the quantity of food and agricultural imports included in the FAOSTAT database is expressed in terms of weight (tones) for all commodities except for live animals which are expressed in units (heads); poultry, rabbits, pigeons and other birds are expressed in thousand units. As a general rule, trade quantity refers to net weight, excluding any sort of container. It includes also food aid quantity. Value of agricultural imports: Value of agricultural imports should be reported in national currency, US dollars or other currency. Import values are mostly reported as CIF (cost insurance and freight). In the FAOSTAT database import values are expressed in thousand US dollars
ELEMENTS:
Export Quantity [1000 heads]
Export Quantity [No]
Export Quantity [heads]
Export Quantity [t]
Export Value [1000 USD]
Import Quantity [1000 heads]
Import Quantity [No]
Import Quantity [heads]
Import Quantity [t]
Import Value [1000 USD]

Export Value [1000 USD]
Import Quantity [t]
Import Value [1000 USD]

Inclusions: The following transactions are generally included in international trade in goods statistics: Barter trade, goods on consignment, goods on financial lease, goods traded between enterprises under common ownership, goods traded on government account and goods with a view or following processing. Exclusions: The following transactions are excluded from international trade in goods statistics for conceptual or methodological reasons:  Goods in simple transit, Temporary trade, Particular trade not subject of a commercial transaction, Supply for national arm forces stationed abroad, embassies and emergency aid for disaster areas, Means of payment and monetary gold and Goods for and after repair.

endorsed the proposed implementation programme, including the preparation of the revision of International Merchandise Trade Statistics: Compilers Manual2 and supporting technical assistance activities (see E/2010/24, chap. I.B, decision 41/103, para. (b)). In the same decision (para. (c)), the Commission requested the Expert Group on International Merchandise Trade Statistics and the Task Force on International Merchandise Trade Statistics to continue their work, focus on the implementation of IMTS 2010 and give due consideration to national circumstances, the harmonization of national and regional compilation practices and the conduct of related comparison studies. The  legal acts concerning the trade statistics at national levels are available on the country websites."

institutionalMandateDataSharing.EN: Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with UNSD on the implementation of IMTS and the data exchange, Mutual agreement with Eurostat on data sharing, cooperation WTO on accessing the CDS database in order to update the Total merchandise statistics.

releaseCalendar.EN:
Dates for new data releases are pre-announced on the FAOSTAT3 website.
In line with FAO’s Statistics Code of Practice data are disseminated on FAO's website  respecting professional independence and in an objective, professional and transparent manner in which all users are treated equitably.

clarity.EN:
The FAO trade statistics is implemented according to the IMTS methodology and standards adopted by the UN Statistics Commission and implemented by UNSD. The main methodologies on trade statistics are available at: http://unstats.un.org/unsd/trade/imts/imts_default.htm 
No quality reports or studies made by FAO.  No national quality reports collected. However, data are carefully reviewed and checked by FAO at least twice per year.

confidentialityPolicy.EN:
According to the confidentiality recommendations formulated by IMTS compiler manual. Country confidentiality rules are available in the national publications or websites.
FAO Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, Principle 10: "All data subject to national confidentiality policies (e.g. concerning people and legal entities, or small aggregates) are kept strictly confidential, and are used exclusively for statistical purposes, or for purposes mandated by legislation."

confidentialityDataTreatment.EN: IMTS recommendations on trade data confidentiality are applied by FAO on trade statistics. In particular only the aggregated data (by FCL classification) are disseminated on the external website. The detailed trade data reported by countries by 8-12 digits HS code and by partners are not disseminated on the external FAOSTAT website. The detailed trade data is only disseminated in the internal FAOSTAT website in order to be shared with all internal FAO users (to eliminate the duplication of the data collection) under TF_source database:http://faostat.local.fao.org/site/588/default.aspx

qualityAssessment.EN: The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

qualityAssurance.EN:
"The FAO Statistics Quality Assurance Framework is available http://www.fao.org/docrep/019/i3664e/i3664e.pdf
The FAO trade data processing system incorporate various data quality modules manly to identify the data inconsistencies as the trade unit value outliers, discrepancies between the reporting data and the trading partner declarations, global trade unbalance by item or group of items etc ."

accuracyNonSampling.EN:
The main source of errors is the deviation from the standard IMTS methodology and recommendations in reporting annual trade data by various countries.  Incomplete country metadata is another source of errors especially on the description of the unit of measurement used at the very detailed level of reporting data. Trade data accuracy is affected by specific characteristics such as the practice of concealing confidential information and the exemption thresholds applied by countries in order to reduce the burden on enterprises. The lack of country tariff line description generate various ambiguities on the link between HS and FCL. Another sources of errors is generated by the current FAO trade data processing system which is over 10 years old.  It is expected to be replaced in order to create new facilities on trade data validation. The FAOSTAT working system, which is also obsolete, is soon to be replaced.
The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

accuracySampling.EN: The national trade statistics is an exhaustive survey which implies that no samples are used. Only on EU intra-trade statistics is the trader operator survey regularly implemented.  According to the EU intra-stat methodology the sampling error is about 2-3%.

revisionPolicy.EN: Preliminary trade data reported by certain countries are substituted by the final trade data if reported. In some cases the missing trade data are also updated according to the new data sources received

revisionPractice.EN: Usually, the revised data for n-1 to n-5 is included in the global validation of the trade data; cross checking with other trade data bases is also used to updated the trade statistics in the last 5 years.

userNeeds.EN:
The trade data quality is always monitored and the "flag system" is helping to identify the official reported data versus estimated, imputed or missing data. According to the annual FAO trade monitor system about 95% of the total merchandise trade statistics is officially reported by countries. For the missing data the imputation methods using the mirror data are applied.

The main user of the annual trade statistics is the internal system used for the compilation of the SUA/FBS. The trade data received by FAO are also shared with Fishery department and other FAO units. Many other FAO analysts are consulting the FAOSTAT trade database or the internal trade databases, other international organizations. Another users are:  NGOs , trade and professional associations, research institutes and universities, journalists and general public. So far no unmet user needs have been recorded.

userSatisfaction.EN: No user satisfaction studies have been conducted  on trade module of FAOSTAT.  However, feed-back from users are recorded. A user satisfaction survey was conducted some years ago on global FAOSTAT dissemination website.

completeness.EN: As mentioned above (see 12.2) about 5% of total trade is missing and the information is imputed using the mirror statistics.

comparabilityGeographical.EN: The mirror data cross checking is one of the methods used to validate trade data. The inconsistency between the declaration of the reporter and partner countries could be generated by the trade methodology applied /general trade system versus special trade system, the latter in the case of extra-EU trade statistics)) by the classification used as well as by the country coverage. Geographical comparability depends on which countries and groups of countries that are compared.  For some countries the comparability is fairly good whilst for others it is less good. It should be noted, however, that accuracy and comparability is very much dependent on customs practices, definitions and policies in individual countries. It shold also be noted that of all the customs activities only a few dimensions are collected purely for statistical purpose.

comparabilityTime.EN: Break in time series could be generated by the changes on the country classifications( see issue such as Sudan and South Sudan and the enlargement of the EU) as well as due to the revision of the HS classification (version 2007 is currently used but for 2012 reference year the HS2012 will be implemented) .  For periods when data are compiled according to one and the same HS classification comparability over time is rather good.

coherenceIntern.EN:
FAO trade data have rather good coherence with FAO production data and producer price data, at least for certain countries, as they are based on the same classifications. Apart from the International Trade Statistics, information on trade flows can be found in National Accounts, Business Statistics and Balance of Payments. The compilation of the data and the production of the above mentioned statistics follow the recommendations (sources and methods) of different international organisations, i.e. Eurostat, International Monetary Fund (IMF), United Nations (UN), etc. The Quality Report on International Trade Statistics documents the main differences between these sources in terms of concepts and definitions, statistical unit or object, classification used, geographical breakdown, reference period and correction methods.
The internal coherence of data are generally good.

timeliness.EN: Data are uploaded for dissemination twice a year, irrespectively when they arrive at FAO.

punctuality.EN: Annually about 140 countries report regularly trade statistics.

label.EN: Other sources and mixture of data source

rawDataDescription.EN: Until 2012, FAO sent a trade data requests to all the countries and then in June the FAO-UNSD joint letter was sent. As from 2012, ESS has stopped sending the trade data requests, except for the joint FAO-UNSD follow up request which was sent by UNSD in July 2012.

dataCollection.EN:
"The main source is official statistics from FAO member countries.  Other sources are: 1. WFP food aid data base – to capture the food aid data which is not included into the commercial trade and is missing from UNSD and GTIS database
2. WTO-CDS – this is Common data set, consolidated data base on total merchandise trade, maintained by WTO with the contribution of UNSD, OECD, ITC etc
3. IMF annual exchange rate – used to convert national currency into US $ 
4. National web databases, national and international publications to update the  trade data for the non reporting countries which are missing from COMTRADE and GTIS
Exceptionally, unofficial data are also used as well as imputed data.  the data is ""flagged"". 
The statistical value: International trade in goods statistics apply harmonised principles when compiling the statistical value of trade flows. In general all goods should be valued with the total amount which would be invoiced in case of sale or purchase at the national border of the reporting country. The statistical value does not include taxes on export or import, such as customs duties, value added tax, excise duty, levies, export refunds or other taxes with similar effect. It includes only incidental expenses (freight, insurance) incurred, in the case of exports/dispatches, in the part of the journey located on the territory of the reporting Member State and, in the case of imports/arrivals, in the part of the journey located outside the territory of the reporting country. It is said to be a FOB value (free on board), for exports/dispatches, and a CIF value (cost, insurance, freight) for imports/arrivals.
